body:
Before the linked commit, "symlinks" to non-existent files didn't work since they were created as junctions. After the commit, "symlinks" to non-existent directories are created as regular symlinks and thus don't work.

It looks like we have to track the intended target type of an "unresolved" symlink, that is, one declared via `ctx.actions.declare_directory`. Unless we find a way to have a type-independent symlink-like object on Windows.

CC @tjgq @meteorcloudy

I think the simplest solution given the constraints might be something along these lines:

1. Add a `FileSystem#createSymbolicLink` overload receiving a "type hint"
2. Modify `WindowsFileSystem#createSymbolicLink` to create the junction/symlink appropriately based on the hint (other filesystems may use a default implementation that ignores the hint)
3. Modify `RemoteActionFileSystem` to detect the case when the symlink target path matches one of the action's inputs, and use the type of that input (as given by its metadata, i.e., without examining the on-disk state) as the hint when calling `FileSystem#createSymbolicLink`.

I don't have the time to work on this right now, but I'd happily review a PR.

Oh, but this only works if the symlink target is a `declare_directory` or `declare_file`. If it's a target path it cannot work, because the target won't be an input to the action that creates the symlink.

> Oh, but this only works if the symlink target is a declare_directory or declare_file.

It's possible that rules_js could be modified to not use `target_path`, and use `target_file` instead, although I don't have context behind that choice.

What if either `ctx.actions.symlink` or `ctx.actions.declare_symlink` were to take a type hint? Would that be viable?

If nothing else works, adding a hint argument to `ctx.actions.symlink` doesn't sound entirely unreasonable; I'd make it so you can only use it with `declare_symlink`, since for `declare_file`/`declare_directory` there's an obviously correct choice that we should be able to make as described above. But that's also a question for the Rules API subteam.

Can we first get to the bottom of why `rules_js` is unable to use `target_file`?
cc @gregmagolan since you seemed to have written [that code](https://github.com/aspect-build/rules_js/blob/03bde54fd8e3de4c57e84247dffef9c450d956d5/npm/private/utils.bzl#L70-L76) in rules_js.

> Can we first get to the bottom of why rules_js is unable to use target_file?

It seems the only usage that can't trivially use `target_file` is [this](https://github.com/aspect-build/rules_js/blob/03bde54fd8e3de4c57e84247dffef9c450d956d5/npm/private/npm_package_store.bzl#L333). This was introduced in https://github.com/aspect-build/rules_js/pull/1646, and seems to purposefully not copy the package sources into a directory.

@comius What are your thoughts on adding a "type hint" argument to `ctx.actions.symlink` (only meaningful on Windows and in conjunction with `target_path`) to instruct Bazel whether to create a "file symlink" or "directory symlink" (which are different kinds of filesystem object on Windows, unlike Unix)?

issue.title: Cannot symlink source directories with declare_directory

labels.name: team-Rules-API
labels.description: API for writing rules/aspects: providers, runfiles, actions, artifacts

repository.name: bazel
repository.description: a fast, scalable, multi-language and extensible build system

issue.body:
### Description of the bug:


Source directories cannot be symlinked by using an output declared using `ctx.actions.declare_directory`, whereas generated directories can. This means this cannot be used as a type of hint for whether to create a file or directory symlink on Windows (see https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/issues/26701).

This could be the same root cause as https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/issues/12954, which is another case where source directories are not considered to be directories.

### Which category does this issue belong to?

Core

### What's the simplest, easiest way to reproduce this bug? Please provide a minimal example if possible.


Ive created a reproducer here: [bazel-symlink-source-dir.tar.gz](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21601992/bazel-symlink-source-dir.tar.gz)

Building `:generated_directory_symlink` works fine, but the similar `:source_directory_symlink` does not, giving the following error:

```
Error in symlink: symlink() with "target_file" file param requires that "output" be declared as a file (did you mean to use declare_file() instead of declare_directory()?)
```

### Which operating system are you running Bazel on?


Ubuntu

### What is the output of `bazel info release`?


release 8.3.1

### If `bazel info release` returns `development version` or `(@non-git)`, tell us how you built Bazel.


N/a

### What's the output of `git remote get-url origin; git rev-parse HEAD` ?


```text
N/a
```

### If this is a regression, please try to identify the Bazel commit where the bug was introduced with bazelisk --bisect.


N/a

### Have you found anything relevant by searching the web?

No

### Any other information, logs, or outputs that you want to share?

No

body:
> It seems the only usage that can't trivially use target_file is [this](https://github.com/aspect-build/rules_js/blob/03bde54fd8e3de4c57e84247dffef9c450d956d5/npm/private/npm_package_store.bzl#L333).

Unfortunately one of the other cases isn't trivial too, but only because I run into this bug: https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/issues/26705

Considering all the constraints, I think adding a "type hint" when only a string path is given is fine. I can't really find any good alternatives. 

One risk is that the wrong value on Linux won't result in an error in some cases. But I wouldn't worry too much about it.
Just to add a +1 to this issue; we are blocked on moving to bazel 8 in our js repos due to this; and we require bazel 8 for fixes to some other issues we are facing
